replies.context:
The offensive by US and ROK forces out of the Pusan Perimeter was timed to coincide with MacArthur's landing at Inchon.  Kim Il-sung's communist "North" Korean Army was largely destroyed.  Communist China, under the dictator Mao, entered the war in October 1950.  The communist dictator Stalin also sent fighter aircraft and pilots.  A number of Stalin's Red Airforce pilots were KIA in Korea.
Stalin gave the "go ahead" order to the communist dictator Kim Il-sung in the Spring of 1950.  Kim Il-sung launched his invasion of the Republic of Korea in June 1950.  The armistice that effectively ended the Korean War was signed on July 27, 1953.  The communist dictator Stalin had died on March 5, 1953.

context:
The Korean War started on June 25, 1950, when the army of the communist dictator of "North" Korea, Kim Il-sung, invaded "South" Korea (Republic of Korea).   Kim Il-sung had received the "go ahead" order from the communist dictator Stalin, during the Spring of 1950.  Stalin had received his first atomic weapons in 1949.  He was also emboldened by the fact that the communist dictator Mao had conquered "mainland" China in 1949.  Stalin actually supplied fighter aircraft and pilots to aid the "North" Korean communists.  A number of Red Airforce pilots were KIA in Korea. 
Stalin, the dictator of the evil communist empire, the USSR, died on March 5, 1953.  The armistice effectively ending the war was signed on July 27, 1953.
A good basic book on the war is:
"The Korean War 1950-1953", by Carter Malkasian

context: My Dad, U.S. Marine, served on the front lines of Korea from 1950 to 1953; he was there until the war ended.  Our intelligence said there were over 3,000 imbedded in those hills, but Dad said, there were over 10,000 and he was there when they came out of their holes.  We lost Dad earlier this year.  He was truly a wonderful person and father; the best of the best!!

context: Did two tours in South Korea, walked the Inchon Battlefield twice. It was a stroke of genius. The "Forgotten War" in Korea was a nightmare. The terrain and weather is terrible, you bake in the summer, during monsoon season you float away and the winters you froze. As a Infantryman myself, from Chosin to Pusan, Soldiers and Marines did the impossible and saved South Korea.

My father was in the occupation of Japan and was first in the Korean conflict at the Pusan parameter later landing at Inchon then again at Wonson and marched to the Chosen reservoir where they were routed (decimated) by the Chinese army and retreated back to Wonson along with 1st Marine division. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not retreating, we‚Äôre advancing in a different direction‚Äù said Maj. Gen. O. P. Smith during their withdrawal. The fighting was terrible. My father was in the 7th Army on the other side of the reservoir and they ceased to exist. My father was a quad 50cal gunner, anti aircraft fighting an army with no air support. They used their guns as an infantry gun and still could not stop the thousands of advancing Chinese.
